perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a strict deadline (30 days) and requires a 'certified' statement showing precise financial data. The modified text replaces these with vague terms like 'reasonable time,' 'should furnish,' 'deems appropriate,' 'generally acceptable', 'approximate sales' and 'estimated values'. This introduces ambiguity, making it difficult for Marv to enforce accurate and timely reporting. This contradicts generally accepted accounting principles and introduces ambiguity around compliance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) and basic contract enforcement principles

perturbation.original_text: THI shall reimburse Marv for all IP Costs incurred on behalf of THI, as well as pre-paid IP Costs incurred prior to the Effective Date of this Agreement, including the costs of provisional and non-provisional applications that are filed to preserve Intellectual Property. Reimbursement for pre-paid IP Costs shall be in accordance with 2 (b) 2 above.
perturbation.changed_text: THI may reimburse Marv for some IP Costs at its discretion. Any previous or future costs do not require to be reimbursed unless pre-agreed.
perturbation.explanation: The original text establishes a clear and mandatory obligation for THI to reimburse Marv for all IP costs. The modified text uses 'may reimburse' and 'at its discretion' which makes the reimbursement obligation voluntary, contradictory and ambiguous. It also introduces additional ambiguity by stating that 'Any previous or future costs do not require to be reimbursed unless pre-agreed,' making the reimbursement of costs discretionary rather than mandatory. This contradicts general principles of contract law, which dictates that previously agreed upon obligations must be followed.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding consideration and obligation

perturbation.original_text: Before payment of any IP Cost, Marv shall notify THI for a time period being the lesser of (i) at least sixty (60) days before the IP Cost is due or (ii) as soon as is practicable after receiving knowledge of the IP Cost. The notice will identify (i) the Application or Patent, (ii) the country, (iii) the reason for the IP Cost, and (iv) the Due Date for payment. THI shall then affirm or deny payment. Affirmation of payment must be received by Marv within fourteen (14) days of the mailing date of the notice or the THI shall be deemed to have denied payment.
perturbation.changed_text: Marv will attempt to notify THI of IP Costs in a reasonable timeframe. THI may or may not affirm or deny payment depending on the circumstances.
perturbation.explanation: The original text establishes a clear process for notifying THI about IP costs and for THI to respond and affirm payment. This is replaced with vague language like 'attempt to notify' and 'reasonable timeframe,' and 'THI may or may not', creating ambiguities. This ambiguity makes it unclear when and how IP costs will be addressed, impacting the protection of intellectual property. This also goes against the general principle of contracts to make timely decisions and follow-up on costs.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding timely decision-making and follow-up on payments.
